title: Which star rejected Lord of the Rings role?
text:
Email a friend 
WHEN it comes to regrets, Nicolas Cage has none. Not even turning down a starring role in one of the highest grossing film series of all time. 
The 51-year-old actor says he knocked back the opportunity to play Aragorn in The Lord of the Rings trilogy (the part went to Viggo Mortensen), but he’s not beating himself up over it. 
Or at least, that’s what he told Newsweek . 
“I don’t really have any regrets,” he said, when asked about some of his movie choices. “I think regret is a waste of time.” Winning ... Nicolas Cage took home the Academy Award for Best Actor in 1996. Susan Sarandon won Best Actress. Pictures: Supplied Source: Supplied 
The star of the upcoming film Pay the Ghost , a horror about a professor whose son is kidnapped during a Halloween parade, says that roles “find” him, rather than the other way around. 
However, he admits that despite having some 80 film credits to his name (including Moonstruck , Leaving Las Vegas , City of Angels and Gone in Sixty Seconds ), there are movies that he wishes he’d done. 
“I try to always move forward as opposed to dwelling on the past or the movies that might have happened,” he told Newsweek . “There certainly were movies that I probably would have benefited from if circumstances in my life allowed me to make them.” No regrets ... Nicolas Cage says he turned down the role of Aragorn in ‘Lord of the Rings’. Source: Supplied Lost role ... Actor Viggo Mortensen played Aragorn in 'The Lord of the Rings' — a part Nicolas Cage says he rejected. Picture: Roadshow Source: News Limited 
When asked to specify which movies he was alluding to, Cage said, “Lord of the Rings. That trilogy. Aragorn. Or The Matrix.” 
It turns out Cage was offered the role of Aragorn in The Lord of the Rings , but turned it down as he wasn’t able to be way for home for such a long duration (the film series was shot on location in New Zealand over eight years). But he insists, it’s all for the best, as now he can enjoy just watching the films — like the rest of us. 
“But the thing is about those movies, I can watch them. I can enjoy them as an audience member. I don’t really watch my own movies. And so I genuinely do have the joy of watching these — especially with Lord of the Rings .” Lord of the Rings
